newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain's Santander seen boosting profitability.
newsitem.headline: Spain's Santander seen boosting profitability.

text.p: Spain's banking giant Santander presented on Tuesday a plan to boost profitability in the medium term while increasing activity in Latin America.

The bank set three goals, an 18-20 percent return on equity over three years versus 1996's 15.6 percent, a minimun compound annual growth for earning per share of 15 percent versus 13.6 in 1996 and a reduction in the ratio of operating costs to operating margin to 55 percent from 63 percent last year.

"We don't want to be the biggest, but the best. We want to be compared with the better banks around the world and to have the highest profitability", chairman Emilio Botin told reporters in a news conference.
Botin added that Santander had gained a prominent position in the Spanish banking system thanks to a policy adopted 10 years ago, while its profits rose 17 percent.
The bank hopes to increase commercial banking activities, with a return on equity at 38 percent in 1996, as well as business in Latin America.
A statement added the market value of Santander investments abroad now stands at US$ 8.451 billion which implies latent capital gains of more than 500 billion pesetas, or US$ 3.95 billion.
In addition the group currently estimates latent gains in its portfolio of government debt of more than US$ 1.4 billion.
Santander's medium-term business line goals include achieving an average contribution to net income by retail banking in Spain of 48 percent and 27 percent for retail banking abroad.

The total book value of banking and financial investments abroad comes to US$ 4.916 billion, representing 42.5 percent of the total group capital. Botin said the 1997 Latin America contribution to the attributable profit should be doubled from the 1996 US$ 200 million.
Botin said Santander has a three percent stake in Empresa de Electricitad National, Endesa and a two percent stake in the Spanish giant Telefonica, which could be increased.

"I do not rule out the possibility to increase that stake because they are doing fine," said Botin adding that Santander won't participate in Retevison's auction while it has the intention to sell its remaining 5.5 percent in Airtel.
Santander has a high level of liquid assets, standing at 387 billion pesetas, but Botin said the bank is very cautious before getting involved in new investments.
The new acquisition has to offer a RoE of around 20 percent and its diluted effect does not to last more than two years.
About its once-plagued unit, Banesto, in which Santander has a 50 percent stake, Botin said it was a strategic investment for his group.
He added Santander could sell a five percent stake in Banesto, but no more than that.
